Award.AwardTitle: CEDAR: Secondary Gravity Wave Coupling Dynamics Between the Mid-Latitude Mesosphere and Thermosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the dynamic coupling processes between the Earth's mesosphere and thermosphere. It will yield estimates of the momentum and energy contribution by gravity wave breaking processes occurring in the mesopause region to the thermosphere. Specifically, the mesospheric secondary gravity wave momentum/energy transport and coupling processes in the Southern hemisphere's upper atmosphere will be studied. This project continues an international collaboration involving scientists from the United States and New Zealand. An undergraduate student will be involved and mentored during the project. Results will be made widely available to the scientific community and general insights communicated to the public.
This work will utilize existing ground-based optical imaging, spectrometer and radar measurements combined with space-based measurements in order to investigate the occurrence and characteristics of secondary gravity wave coupling between the mesosphere and thermosphere. The project will build upon recent observations at Mt. John Observatory, New Zealand of secondary gravity waves generated by gravity waves breaking at a lower altitude region in the mesosphere near 100 km altitude. The New Zealand region is a known "hotspot" of gravity wave activity in the southern hemisphere, a region of the globe under-represented in terms of upper atmospheric observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was submitted originally as a 3-year proposal but it was awarded as 1-year project. The report is for that 1-year project.

The major goals of the project were:

1. To build upon the results of Smith et al. (2013) i.e., the discovery of secondary gravity waves (GW?s) in the thermosphere at ~250 km altitude in optical all-sky images of night-time 630.0 nm airglow emission over New Zealand (see Figure 1).

Airglow is a faint glow that occurs naturally across the entire sky during the night-time hours. Gravity waves are oscillation in the atmosphere that arise due to some type of disturbance. They appear as moving ripples in all-sky images of the night-time sky similar to ripples moving on a pond.

The images were obtained by a state-of-the-art all-sky imager located at the Mt. John Observatory in the South Island of New Zealand. The secondary waves appear to be the result of gravity waves breaking at a lower region of the upper atmosphere, in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) at 80-100 km altitude.

2. To identify further secondary gravity wave candidates and perform a survey to determine their characteristics, variability, and possible generation processes/mechanisms associated with the waves.

What we did:

A total of 150 candidate events from the Mt John Observatory image database were analyzed. We investigated the frequency of occurrence, seasonal variability, and local time periods of occurrence. We obtained and combined co-located Fabry-Perot interferometer wind and temperature data to characterize the propagation environment in the MLT and thermosphere where the GW activity was occurring.

1. To produce a coherent and logical classification of the thermospheric GW?s in order to ascertain their identity as truly secondary GW phenomenon.

2. Determine the characteristics, seasonal and diurnal variability, and possible generation processes/mechanisms associated with the secondary thermospheric waves.

What we found:

1. We found that secondary gravity waves in the thermosphere occurrence relatively frequently over the New Zealand landmass; ~50-60 nights per year on average.

2. The phenomenon has not been observed in any of our other all-sky imagers (13 total) around the world and, to our knowledge, it has not been reported previously.

3. The phenomenon exhibits a highly variable but strong annual variation (see Figure 2) with maxima of occurrence in the spring months although the month of December also exhibited a high occurrence rate. A marked decrease in occurrence during the second half of the year with Fall exhibiting a deep minimum. We suspect that the variation in occurrence is related to the seasonal variation in the local wind field, at lower altitudes and in the thermosphere. Further work is required to clarify this finding.

4. The direction of propagation of the secondary waves tends towards the south-east which suggests both a clue regarding the sourcing (orographic forcing of the primary GW?s at lower altitudes) and also a result of filtering by the local thermospheric wind field. 

Relevancy and importance of what we found:

The discovery of large-amplitude GW?s in the thermosphere (Smith et al., 2013) was an important step in understanding the amount of energy and momentum that is actually transported from the lower atmosphere up into the space environment. The vast majority of investigations over the years have focused on the effects of the space environment on the upper atmosphere/ionosphere; phenomena such as aurorae, communication black-outs, irregularities, etc. that arise from solar and geomagnetic activity.

The key outcome of this project was the strong seasonal variation in occurrence exhibited by the phenomenon. The variation is annual with a maximum in occurrence during the winter and early spring and very little activity in the Fall.

Presentations/Publications: 

Some of the results were presented in a talk at the 2016 CEDAR workshop in Santa Fe, NM (19-24 June):

Steven Smith, Jeffery Baumgardner, Michael McCarthy & Michael Mendillo (2016). Large-scale Mesospheric Mountain Wave Breaking During over New Zealand during DEEPWAVE 2014. NSF CEDAR Workshop 2016. Santa Fe, New Mexico, 19-24 June.

The results have been written up and will soon be ready for submission for publication to a scientific journal (e.g Journal Geophysical Research).

Smith, S.M., M. McCarthy, J. Baumgardner, and M. Mendillo (2018), Secondary Thermospheric Gravity Waves in the Southern Mid-Latitudes, J. Geophys. Res, in prep.
